content: The Act titled "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience and a degree in a health-related field. The pilot program selects eligible individuals with medical or military health experience and a degree in a health-related field to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The program lasts for five years and aims to recruit at least 250 participants. The Secretary will select at least 250 eligible individuals with medical or military health experience to participate in the pilot program for a five-year period. Priority will be given to those who participated in a previous program or agree to work as a physician assistant in underserved communities. The pilot program aims to provide educational assistance, including scholarships, for individuals to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies. The program targets a medical facility in a designated medically underserved community with a high percentage of veterans in the population. The pilot program offers scholarships for individuals to pursue a master's degree in physician assistant studies. The Secretary will utilize existing educational assistance programs and provide a minimum of 35 scholarships each year. Participants must agree to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration. The pilot program requires individuals to agree to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service, which can vary based on the program they are participating in. The pilot program for physician assistants at the Veterans Health Administration requires a specified period of obligated service. If an individual fails to meet this obligation, they are liable to repay the amount received under the program. The pilot program for physician assistants at the Veterans Health Administration includes provisions for reducing liability for individuals who fail to complete their obligated service. Mentors are available for participants, and partnerships with institutions of higher education offering master's degree programs are sought. The pilot program at Veterans Health Administration seeks partnerships with institutions of higher education offering master's degree programs in physician assistant studies. These institutions agree to guarantee seats for program participants who meet entrance requirements and provide information on admissions criteria. The pilot program at Veterans Health Administration partners with accredited institutions offering physician assistant studies programs. These institutions guarantee seats for participants who meet entrance requirements and provide admissions information. Additionally, the program is promoted to veterans and members of the Armed Forces through various channels. The Secretary appoints staff within the Office of Physician Assistant Services to administer the program. The Secretary appoints a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants within the Office of Physician Assistant Services to oversee, recruit, and assist individuals participating in the pilot program. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention is responsible for recruiting candidates, coordinating with participants, assisting in master's degree program admissions, providing information, and may work at a medical center. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention is responsible for recruiting candidates, coordinating with participants, assisting in master's degree program admissions, providing information, and may work at a medical center. Additionally, a recruiter is responsible for identifying and coordinating the needs of a pilot program, assisting in providing mentors to participants, coordinating staff at Veterans Health Administration facilities, and working with various offices to develop workforce management and consulting strategies. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention oversees the recruitment of physician assistants and collaborates with various offices to develop national recruiting strategic plans. An administrative assistant at a minimum GS-6 level supports the Office of Physician Assistant Services to ensure effective operations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, must submit a report within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in collaboration with other departments, must submit a report on a pilot program for physician assistants to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The report will assess the program's effectiveness in improving the ability of eligible individuals to become physician assistants and its impact on addressing the shortage of physician assistants in the workforce. The pilot program aims to enable individuals with medical skills from the Armed Forces to join the physician assistant workforce of the Department, addressing the shortage of physician assistants. The report will identify necessary modifications to meet program goals and assess its potential as a model for other healthcare fields. At least $8,000,000 of funding for the program will be sourced accordingly. The pilot program aims to assist individuals in obtaining certification and employment in healthcare fields. Not less than $8,000,000 of funding will be sourced from the Department of Veterans Affairs for the program. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants within the Department of Veterans Affairs. This includes holding medical center directors accountable for program utilization and incentives to advance employees' education as physician assistants. The Department's Education Debt Reduction Program will also be available for participants. The Department of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. This includes ensuring availability of the Education Debt Reduction Program for participants to fill vacant positions and monitoring compliance with the application process. Additionally, programs will be created to incentivize employees' education as physician assistants. The Secretary will monitor compliance with educational assistance programs and create incentives for Department employees to apply to physician assistant programs. Regulations will be prescribed as needed to implement this section. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF PAY GRADES FOR PHYSICIAN ASSISTANTS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS AND REQUIREMENT TO PROVIDE COMPETITIVE PAY. (a) Establishment of Pay Grades.--Section 7404(b) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include pay grades for physician assistants. The text discusses the establishment of pay grades for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs and the requirement to provide competitive pay. It also mentions the implementation of a national strategic plan for the retention and recruitment of physician assistants, focusing on competitive pay standards compared to the private sector. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing standards for competitive pay for physician assistants compared to the private sector. The Secretary must submit a report on the implementation of the national strategic plan within one year of the Act's enactment.
